text: Emerson Community Experience
How could Emerson engage you in building a stronger inclusive and equitable community?
Discuss racism, anti-Semitism all forms of discrimination pro-actively. A consistent and educational campaign for staff, faculty and students
Regular communication
give staff time for this work
Engagement
Transparent and consistent support for marginalized students
Send a message from the top of the organization that Emerson trusts its faculty and staff, and is dedicated to providing resources and flexibility to support integrating a diverse pool of talent.
I feel like the College has done a good job of engaging with me in this capacity.
I think students are engaged or would be more engaged if it felt like we were being listened to and saw change first hand. Words only take you so far
Showing up
I wish I had a good answer for this. People are exhausted and burned out in our 3rd pandemic year. Everyone is trying to push through, hoping for a break to recharge and imagine.
Engage from the perspective of staff
Invest in staff

specific but by allowing us to zoom into class especially when exposed or infected. absolutely unacceptable that I had to choose between my VERY expensive education and keeping my community safe. extremely ableist, inequitable, and immoral

I value social interactions with my peers especially who share my identity and often times I am unaware who they are because I am usually an uncommon identity in my classes. I would love to meet with other BIPOC students and be more involved.
Compensate work that supports social justice, equity, and justice (e.g. compensate staff/students/faculty for participation on an extra committee or extra obligation)

Student, faculty, staff are often viewed as three separate components/communities. There could be more collaboration between the three so all moving forward together and more supporting each other in getting the goals accomplished.
How can Emerson engage me?
hiring more diverse staff, building promotion paths to retain them
Identify the gaps. (eg When had the Pres. last met with the staff?)
Give us the time and money to do this.

Literature is available that describes Restorative Justice and Trauma-Informed Practices (not just teaching). I'd like to see the college invest in figuring out what potential those models hold and how it could work within a college setting.
just do it already
Employ the "curricula" you teach and posted words in practice not just on social media
Restorative Justice
What are we trying to achieve
spend the money to support the community
By compensating everyone (especially diverse colleagues of color) appropriately for their labor.
Actually take exit interview seriously and enact changes based on that feedback.

When elements of the college are told their efforts are inadequate for disabled or medically compromised people, there should be a solution provided that is not dehumanizing, does not require staff to jump through hoops.
Emerson needs to engage diverse students, faculty, and staff (particularly of color) and enact changes based on their experiences instead of just creating new review committees.
time needs to be made, like this survey, for staff to think through these subject
provide specific examples of policies and practices to change
Yes, I hope specific policy and practice changes will come from BRE's work.
Start Staff Training
Get staff to recognize and report inequity
Individuals DO have an imporant part in this
Compensation, Recognition & Appreciation
stop raising tuition, take COVID more seriously, take concerns from BIPOC students more seriously
Willing to provide opinions and work towards end goal
By compensating me appropriately for my work
Community Members cannot work for change if they are scraping by
So tired.
Evident need to reduce community fatigue
me too
Providing more options for classes that double as requirements that focus on diversity and equity
Diversifying the classroom
Emerson-sponsored events that celebrate many different cultures
Agreed
Really look at everyone
please flesh out
establish task forces/committees responsible for creating measurable goals/timelines with representation from students/faculty/staff
Emerson needs to create an environment that is more results-focused on many levels.
There already are committees and groups and a lot of it is really performative and nothing gets done

I think the really important part of this is "measurable goals," because Emerson really likes to create task forces only to produce statements like "we will try REALLY hard not to be racist anymore," without creating any concrete rulings"
This is already happening and it's not enough
Come together to listen to all voices.
There appears to be a disconnect between the equity values Emerson espouses and the student experience. Why do you think this is?
Students are treated like the enemies instead of the customers
The College really needs to look into and understand where the anti-sematic and racial comments are originating.
Unsure
not enough staff
Disconnect
Students experience Emerson in different ways and we need better resources, services and systems to aid all students.
We have a lot of wonderful idealist/visionary leaders, but fewer realists dedicated to implementation. We need a good balance of both.
I think the College can do better at sharing their story and the change they are working to enact. I don't think students are always aware of what is going on behind the scenes.
Emerson can not continue to be all talk we need to see real change. We need action.
Lack of Accountability & Support
We live in a capitalistic white supremacist society. People are trying to make changes, but laws, culture and capitalism push against them.
Disconnect
the university is not talking to students enough; the decision makers are widely older white men
Students may possibly be unaware the efforts Emerson faculty are making. If they are not aware of the processes and changes in place they may not connect it to their personal Emerson experience.
Power doesn't want to give up power
There should be more transparency about what has happened, what is happening, and what Emerson's plans are for the future
Emerson is highly reactive vs. proactive when it comes to equity
The staff and faculty tasked to create spaces based in equity aren't living up to those values
Sometimes what we can deliver doesn't match up with student expectations. And sometimes we just get it wrong.
Emerson sets lofty standards and goals, but does not provide funding or support to meet them.
"Caring" takes space, time, and energy. These values will not trickle down if faculty, staff, and students continue to be overworked.
Those closest to pain not closest to power
administration unwilling to make systemic changes and rather relegates the issue to individual people and opportunities
not investing in equity and justice work at the college
not following through with addressing student demands
Lack of care/understanding/concern
A certain lack of understanding or engagement by those who make decisions at the college
The action does not meet needs
Decisions are made with money as the primary motivating factor, instead of people.
Student feedback and reports of their experience don't seem to be taken seriously, and future students are discouraged from reporting/sharing because of the poor past experiences of others.
Emerson may say that it espouses certain values, but it does very little to actually back them up with action. There seems to be a disconnect because there is a disconnect.
can't be all things to all people
lack of communication
Administration talks a nice talk but is slow to enact actual change
You can't have it both ways
Changes takes time; students aren’t always aware of what is happening to create change
Poor communication isn't an excuse
Support throughout
Lack of understanding
It is easy to espouse ideals without actually following through on them. This seems to be the student experience - Emerson has great ideas but fails to put many in place
Performance and Branding
Emerson's perception of equity is a business model and a marketing strategy
Bingo
Students, faculty, and staff are not held accountable for their inequitable actions
Accountability and consequences go hand in hand, without consequences-how does the behavior change
Accountability is key because without it inequity is rampant
because at the end of the day, it's clear that Emerson is first and foremost a business, dedicated to making money, rather than education

If it doesn't make money, it can't pay for innovative faculty who advance equity or offer more scholarships, or seek to expand the trainings and practices needed to become more accessible. How EC seeks money and uses it matters, however.
Capitalism doesn't exclude equity, compassion or awareness
Emerson exists in a capitalistic society
Money
We need to listen to what students are saying about their experiences. And then create a means to improve what is not working.
Student Voices
Marketing vs reality
How can Emerson improve diversity and equity at the college?
Hire diverse staff on the admission team.
Tolerance for different points of view. Respect for all people. Even those with whom you disagree
Increase wages and financial aid
Past harm needs to be addressed at new social justice ctr
More scholarships
More access
Transparency on out-of-pocket costs for classes; additional emergency aid; industry connections for first-gen/low-income students
Management training, providing resources for flexibility and integration of diverse faculty/staff, trust employees
recruiting, hiring, supporting, connecting
Identifying and eliminating barriers for success

I'm no expert but as a queer, trans, learning disabled, jewish student I want to see people like me and people nothing like me represented. International media and literature should be normal in a classroom setting. 0 tolerance for hate.
hire more BIPOC professors and give them the resources they need
provide more economic resources for students
Connection Across Depts

Everyone will want to say training/workshops, but let's be real about what sitting through a session can & cannot do. I think the real answer is culture change and setting base expectations (which is squishy and nebulous and hard to put on a checklist.)
Improving equity
More need-based scholarships (NOT the honors program! which already disadvantages students)

invest more money in programs and students that are advocating for equity; giving more financial aid (or how about lowering tuition significantly bc its ridiculous); hiring more diverse staff (most of my profs are white men)
normalize disability
Center folx most marginalized
Open spaces for online students of color to connect, such as a student chapter of NBASLH or discipline specific organization in a student's field of study.
Hire more administrative staff so they aren't burnt out
Build more support systems for marginalized students
Create transparent and formal processes for how bias reports are handled at Emerson
Ensure faculty are prepared to facilitate dialogue in a diverse classroom and support marginalized students
Recruit and admit more BIPOC students

Create more pathways (like EmersonWrites/Emerson Theater) for students at younger ages to be exposed to communication and the arts fields they may not otherwise have access to. More financial aid needed.
What can Emerson do?
give the new VP for Equity and Social Justice a significant budget - money talks and makes things happen
All encompassing approach to DEI
Examine exit interviews for identified areas of failure, and build plans to repair
FUND the initiatives that come out of these listening sessions. It is not enough to assign these initiatives to current staff with no additional funding or shifting of workload.
Greater exploration of the impact and possibilities of the Board of Trustees and their stances on pursuing equity at Emerson.
I don't hear much about equity and the needs of our grad or commuter students but would like to.
The students have already provided several detailed lists on how we can address these issues
Accountability from the top down
Employing people who care
Identify ownership of issues
This question has already been answered
Mandatory, rigorous diversity, equity, and bias training for every entering employee, and frequent required refreshers.
Board of Trustees needs to fundraise and allot more dollars to full scholarships specifically meant to recruit and be able to retain diverse students.
Actually pursue diversity and equity with pro-active action. Recruit diverse faculty and staff and pay them what their labor is worth (and equitably with their colleagues).
more resources are needed to get Emerson where it wants to be
Continue Hiring efforts and Start with the promised trainings
Training absolutely matter and should be in place. I wonder, though, how accountability and infrastructure can help what is learned during training to take root?
Diversity Training
Financial Investment
allow student workers to work above 20 hr limit (grad students take few classes and need the hours!!!)
more scholarship money for students financially struggling
provide more scholarship funds for students.
Putting words into action
Values and vision match
By taking a thorough look at how EC is upholding the tenets of White Supremacy Culture and how they can transform the college into a space where everyone can thrive
Consult students about mandated procedures like weekly COVID testing
invites students with chronic illness to share experiences/hardships
Not relevant to the conversation

Retention of BIPOC staff and faculty
Reframing/redesigning DiversityEdu for students and equity training for faculty
Training=Awareness=Change

I would add performance expectations/accountability/growth tracking or something similar here because awareness doesn't always lead to change- especially if the resources or agency to make changes is limited.
Firing tenured professors who students have spoken out against for their inequitable teaching
Makes space to hire more equitable professors
Providing financial aid for marginalized and in-need students

literally be willing to make changes from the top up, rather than just making groups to discuss issues that don't solve any actual issues
Holds administration responsible

give them back their name

What are your top three diversity and equity concerns at Emerson?
Equal pay, titles that reflect the work being done, a defensive posture whenever issues are brought up
Welcoming and Respectful Environment. A willingness to be open and non-judgmental
Fair wages for staff and faculty, generous student financial aid, increased diversity in permanent faculty and staff
student activism= better results than staff activism

sustaining successes and momentum
Hiring and retaining staff of color; identifying and addressing barriers for participation in abroad/domestic programs;
Accessibility inside and outside the classroom. I haven't had a single professor of color yet (although I'm only a freshman). The curriculum is still very euro centric

lack of accessibility

how white it is (lack of access for students of color); how expensive it is (related to whiteness); too much talk and not enough action

CSD coursework that prepares clinicians for assessment and treatment in the multicultural landscape of America at all levels of therapy in every setting for all ages.

1: presenting an unintentionally unwelcome environment, 2: under- or over-representing BIPOC experience on campus, 3: institutional contraction and stagnation due to talented people leaving

Accessibility, supporting economic diversity, and addressing intersectionality
Lack of compassion and lack of proactive accommodations for disabled or immunocompromised community members (particularly in regards to the pandemic).
Severe lack of adequate scholarship dollars to recruit and retain diverse students, especially from underserved populations, and a lack of support once they are at Emerson.
I agree. I hope the Office of Student Access and Student Belonging gets the "startup" resources it needs and that it's role and funding will be re-evaluated in order for it to have a deeper impact.
​Recent exodus of faculty and staff of color, especially tenured/longstanding community members.
I agree
diversity of socio-economic backgrounds
Agreed. The additional costs beyond tuition and housing should also be considered.
social media and sound bites sometimes take the place of thorough discussion, different constituencies present contrary goals, lack of trust

What has been most impactful about Emerson’s efforts to build a diverse and equitable community?

I do not know. At times it does not feel very inclusive. It is amazing to me that lip service is given to being inclusive but there seems to a lot bad behavior that does not feel welcoming or respectful.

explain "experience"

Asking faculty to take a critical dive into their classes and recognize where there is room for improvement

learning

I think we have worked hard to expand the reach of the ELA program to a more diverse group of students. We have begun to set-up partnerships with Boston office that can help us in our recruiting efforts.
Emerson still has lots of work to do but I appreciated the fact that the college didn't turn a blind eye to what happened in my class where my prof was blatantly anti semitic
the diversification of reading materials
Listening Skills

The fact that we don't have to argue about whether diversity/inclusion is a good thing or not. We can start from the basis that it is, and disagree what to do next. True, that's a really low bar, but one that is not met in a lot of places.

Student Accessibility Services and the work that they do! Too often diversity and inclusion is focused more on race than on all types of inclusion. The SAS staff is small but mighty and continue to highlight inclusion in different forms.

hiring of Lee Pelton and Sylvia Spears

A coherent strategy of how those individuals and offices work individually and collectively is needed. That does entail collaboration where it makes sense but also I don't think there's a clear understanding of how the various people/offices

the lack of true commitment to enacting change

I have seen over the past few years, from students, staff, and faculty, a real effort to come together and discuss different ways to make our campus more diverse and equitable. I have seen movement in this direction, but there is a lot more work to do.

Helping Students/Families
My relationships with my colleagues and my client groups.
Collaborating with creative people
I appreciate the variety of opportunities that are made for the students. I appreciate the hands on learning experience in the different courses and activities.
not sure
My access to resources and a network I wouldn't have at any other school
Appreciation
Faculty
Creative Environment
Forging new friendships and curricular projects with other faculty members
The smaller size, the ability to innovate
I really appreciate the collaborative nature in which students and staff/faculty are encouraged to work.
I enjoy the amount of different opportunities there are for me to get involved with various organizations. I appreciate that the college strives to better itself.

Passion of Community
Emerson appreciation

That this is a community that believes in and tries to practice values like inclusion, belief in science, antiracism, etc. We fail, because we're human and humans always fall short - but I really appreciate that we start from a place of effort.

The Staff and Students

I appreciate the access to resources and alumni that will almost guarantee me work after college. I appreciate the amount of knowledge I have gained and will continue to gain that is preparing me for my career as a filmmaker.
Awestruck

I have most appreciated the open door/inbox approach towards students that allows them to approach instructors in a low pressure atmosphere. I feel as though I have been respected by all faculty members and encouraged to continue to grow academically.
We have good people who want to make positive change happen.
I love that being creative and bold in my work is encouraged and valued.
I appreciate that we are encouraged to innovate and continually raise the bar on what we do at Emerson.
I appreciate the opportunity to connect with such creative, passionate, and inspiring students
i appreciate that I can have an impact on students AND colleagues

I love being able to connect with students and faculty and help them. I think there is a sense of community among staff members that I appreciate. I think the benefits and the way staff are treated are better than a lot of places I've worked.
The students are the best part of Emerson

What I Appreciate Most
The students

The staff I work with directly are creative, hardworking, and engaged. They are always willing to collaborate and lend a hand when needed. Their focus is on creating the best experience and environment possible for the constituents we serve.

Despite my own experiences, I recognize that staff in other areas than my mown have dealt with microaggressions, interference with their work, and have reported that their team was not receptive to proposed moves towards equity.
I agree with this.

The students are infinitely creative. They also hold high expectations for their education, and the environment in which it is delivered. I learned as much from students as I did in the classroom.
I appreciate being around other creative people who see the world through a similar lens and who don't feel beholden to doing things the "proper" way if it doesn't work for us.
clear articulation of values

I appreciate that I feel like my voice is heard here, and that I am respected by my staff, peers, and supervisors.
